words.context_notes: Universal Spanish profanity, equivalent to 'shit' in English
Very common in Spain, less offensive than English 'fuck'
Vulgar term for female genitalia, very offensive, especially in Latin America
Highly offensive, targets women specifically
Masculine form, can be homophobic slur, severity varies by region
Ranges from mild to offensive depending on region, can mean 'bastard' or be friendly
Common Mexican insult meaning 'idiot' or 'asshole'
Mexican slang, can be homophobic, means 'asshole' literally and figuratively
Son of a whore, very offensive compound insult
Homophobic slur, extremely offensive to LGBTQ+ community
Argentine slang, can be friendly or insulting depending on context
Mexican verb with multiple meanings, from mild to very offensive
Vulgar term for penis, very common in Mexico and Central America
Common expletive, less offensive than English equivalents
Calling someone annoying or a 'sucker', sexual undertones
Spanish insult meaning 'idiot' or 'jerk'
Spanish mild insult, literally 'cocoon' but slang for penis tip
Mexican homophobic slur, extremely offensive
Lesbian slur in Spanish, very offensive
Ethnic slur used in Spain against South Americans, very offensive
Context-dependent, can be neutral or offensive, varies greatly by region
Used as insult in Argentina, originally meaning 'Polish' but used against any immigrant
Chilean/Peruvian slang, can be friendly or insulting, very common
Colombian insult using STD name, moderately offensive
Colombian vulgar term, sexual undertones

category_system.description: Spanish profanity categorization considering regional variations and cultural context
category_system.methodology: Based on Spanish sociolinguistic research and regional usage patterns

general.name: Profanidad General
general.description: Common swear words and mild expletives without specific targeting
general.examples_note: Basic profanity used for emphasis or frustration

sexual.name: Contenido Sexual
sexual.description: Words related to sexual acts, anatomy, or sexually explicit content

subcategories.anatomy: Sexual body parts and references (verga, coño, culo)
subcategories.prostitution: Terms related to sex work (puta, prostituta)

slurs.name: Insultos y Términos Despectivos
slurs.description: Derogatory terms targeting specific groups or individuals
slurs.examples_note: Offensive terms for groups and individuals

subcategories.appearance: Physical appearance insults (feo, gordo usado as slurs)

racial.name: Insultos Raciales
racial.description: Racially charged language and ethnic slurs

religious.name: Profanidad Religiosa
religious.description: Blasphemous or sacrilegious language targeting religious beliefs

violence.name: Violencia y Agresión
violence.description: Words promoting or describing violence, threats, or aggressive behavior

subcategories.threats: Direct or implied threats of harm (te mato)
subcategories.weapons: References to weapons in threatening context
subcategories.death_wishes: Expressions wishing harm or death (que te mueras)

scatological.name: Escatológico
scatological.description: References to bodily waste and bathroom functions

subcategories.crude_anatomy: Crude references to body parts involved

body_parts.name: Partes del Cuerpo Inapropiadas
body_parts.description: Crude or inappropriate references to body parts
body_parts.examples_note: Anatomical terms used inappropriately or crudely

1.description: Generally acceptable in casual conversation but may be filtered in formal settings
1.cultural_notes: Often used in friendly context, especially in Spain

2.description: Inappropriate in most professional or public settings
2.cultural_notes: Context-dependent severity, varies by region and relationship

3.description: Highly offensive and inappropriate in most contexts
3.cultural_notes: Clearly offensive across all Spanish-speaking regions

4.description: Extremely offensive, potentially illegal, or causing significant harm
4.cultural_notes: Hate speech level, can have legal consequences in some countries

spain.tolerance_level: Higher for sexual profanity, lower for religious blasphemy

argentina.tolerance_level: High tolerance for creative insults in informal settings

gender_considerations.agreement_rules: Most Spanish profanity follows grammatical gender agreement
gender_considerations.severity_differences: Some terms more offensive when targeting women (puta vs puto)
gender_considerations.cultural_impact: Machismo culture affects severity of gender-specific terms

cultural_context.description: Cultural context and usage patterns for Spanish profanity across regions
cultural_context.methodology: Based on sociolinguistic research and cultural anthropology studies

family.acceptance_level: Varies by family tradition and region

generational_differences.parents: Context-dependent, often hypocritical (use but don't allow children)
generational_differences.children: Depends on family rules and regional norms

friendship.boundaries: Even close friends avoid certain identity-based slurs

workplace.professional: Zero tolerance in formal business settings
workplace.blue_collar: Higher tolerance, part of workplace culture
workplace.consequences: Can lead to disciplinary action or dismissal

public_spaces.transportation: Generally frowned upon, especially around children
public_spaces.markets: Vendors may use mild profanity casually
public_spaces.formal_public: Completely inappropriate in government, medical, educational settings
public_spaces.consequences: Can lead to social ostracism or official complaints

educational.universities: Somewhat more tolerant in informal student interactions
educational.academic_context: Only acceptable in linguistic research context
educational.teaching_materials: Requires careful handling and content warnings

religious.religious_families: Very low tolerance across all contexts
religious.regional_variations: Spain more secular, Latin America often more religious

television.spain: More permissive, sexual terms after watershed
television.streaming: Content warnings required, varied by platform

print_media.newspapers: Generally avoided except in direct quotes
print_media.magazines: Varies by target audience and region
print_media.academic: Acceptable in linguistic and cultural research

internet.social_media: Generally more permissive, community standards vary
internet.forums: Depends on community rules and moderation

children.exposure: Varies dramatically by region and family
children.education: Sex education may include anatomical terms

adolescents.education: Critical period for understanding appropriate usage

adults.social_navigation: Must read context and audience carefully
adults.parenting_role: Often hypocritical - use but forbid children
adults.regional_adaptation: Must adjust when moving between regions

elderly.regional_patterns: Rural often more conservative than urban
elderly.health_settings: Medical terminology may overlap with profanity
elderly.intergenerational_conflict: May clash with younger family members

traditional_patterns.machismo_influence: Women historically expected to use less profanity
traditional_patterns.double_standards: Same words more offensive when used by or targeting women

evolving_patterns.feminist_reclamation: Some women deliberately using strong profanity
evolving_patterns.generational_change: Younger women more likely to use profanity openly

specific_considerations.puta: Always more offensive than masculine equivalents
specific_considerations.sexual_anatomy: Female anatomy terms generally more taboo
specific_considerations.lgbtq_slurs: Affect perceptions of masculinity and femininity

cultural_factors: Tourism industry affects public language use
unique_aspects: Sexual profanity more accepted than religious
Regional pride affects acceptance of Madrid vs regional terms
Class distinctions still influence language appropriateness

cultural_factors: US border influence on northern regions

unique_aspects: Medical terms used as mild insults
Youth culture creating new terms rapidly

celebratory.context: Excitement and joy can make profanity more acceptable
celebratory.boundaries: Still avoid hate speech and targeted slurs

frustration.context: Emotional release often forgiven in appropriate settings
frustration.escalation_risk: Can escalate to more serious profanity

humor.acceptable: Most profanity acceptable if genuinely funny and not targeting
humor.boundaries: Humor doesn't excuse hate speech or cruel targeting

social.ostracism: Inappropriate usage can lead to social exclusion
social.reputation: Affects how others perceive education and class

professional.industry_variation: Some industries more tolerant than others

legal.public_disturbance: Extreme cases may lead to citations

digital.platform_bans: Social media accounts may be suspended
digital.content_removal: Posts containing profanity may be deleted
digital.permanent_record: Digital trail can affect future opportunities

primary_regions.notes: European Spanish, includes Andalusian and other regional variations
Largest Spanish-speaking population, significant dialectal variation
Includes Uruguay, distinctive voseo and Italian influence
Regional variations between coast, mountains, and plains
Similar to Colombian, some unique regional features
Andean influence, significant indigenous language contact

regional_coverage.coverage_notes: Database focuses on major regional variants with highest speaker populations and most distinctive profanity patterns

phonological: Distinction between /θ/ and /s/ in Spain vs merger in Latin America
Yeísmo: /ʎ/ and /ʝ/ merger in most regions
morphological: Voseo in Argentina and some other regions
syntactic: Flexible word order allows for emphasis
lexical: Anglicisms varying by region and contact level

unique_features: Gender agreement affects severity and usage
Diminutives can soften or intensify meaning
Regional variations in severity and acceptability
Religious and sexual profanity categories distinct

validation_approach: Verify severity levels across different communities
limitations: Rapid language evolution in digital age
Potential researcher bias in severity assessment

research_ethics: Respect for cultural sensitivity across regions

quality_metrics.completeness: Covers major regions and profanity categories
quality_metrics.accuracy: Cross-validated with multiple sources and regions
quality_metrics.currency: Regular updates planned for evolving language
quality_metrics.regional_balance: Attempts to balance major Spanish-speaking regions

technical_notes.encoding: UTF-8 with full diacritical mark support
technical_notes.collation: Spanish alphabetical order with ñ placement

severity_system.description: Spanish profanity severity assessment with cultural and regional considerations
severity_system.methodology: Based on sociolinguistic research across Spanish-speaking regions
severity_system.scale: 1-4 scale where 1 is mild and 4 is extremely offensive

1.name: Leve
1.description: Mild profanity, generally acceptable in informal settings
characteristics: May be filtered in professional settings
Can be diminished with tone and context

2.name: Moderado
characteristics: Severity varies with target and intent

3.name: Fuerte
3.description: Highly offensive across most contexts and regions
characteristics: Can cause offense regardless of intent

regional_notes.social_impact: Can cause lasting harm to individuals and communities

relationship.family: Severity often reduced in family context
relationship.friends: Many terms acceptable or even affectionate

intent.targeted: Increases severity when directed at person

tone.angry: Escalates severity regardless of word choice
tone.emphatic: Increases intensity without necessarily increasing offense

unique_considerations: Medical terms used as mild insults

gender.general_patterns: Some terms more offensive when targeting women

religious_background.evangelical: Very low tolerance for most profanity

mild_to_severe: amigo → cabrón → hijo de la chingada
friendly_to_hostile: cabrón (buddy) → cabrón (asshole) → hijo de tu madre

cultural_notes.diminutives: Can soften severity (putita, cabronito) but also intensify sarcasm
cultural_notes.religious_context: Varies significantly - some regions very sensitive, others not
cultural_notes.historical_usage: Some terms losing/gaining severity over time
cultural_notes.media_influence: Television and music affecting regional acceptance

variation_system.description: Spanish profanity variations including obfuscations, regional forms, and linguistic patterns
variation_system.methodology: Comprehensive collection of spelling variations, l33t speak, and regional dialectal differences

symbol_replacement.asterisks: Replace vowels or consonants with * (p*ta, m*erda)

phonetic_variations.k_for_c: kulo for culo, kabrón for cabrón
phonetic_variations.z_for_s: cozo for coño in some regions

andalusian.dropped_s: Plural forms lose final -s in speech
andalusian.aspirated_s: S becomes h sound before consonants

catalan_influence.structure: Catalan sentence structure in Spanish profanity

nahuatl_influence.cuate: Friend, can be used in insults

examples: andá a la concha de tu madre

context_dependent.generational: Older vs younger speakers have different tolerances
